body:
no idea, I also noticed that. Seems to have been contributed by different individuals? Also, before the age of auto-vectorization which would automatically apply panel transformer to series and vice versa.

Also, they cannot be identical, since the one in the `panel` module outputs primitives, whereas the one in the `series` module outputs series.

This is one of those instances where it would have been really great if the implementers would have written a few lines of math, such as, what is the output object, e.g., in reference to a scientific paper?
We could ask the authors: I know the GitHub ID of @mloning, but do you know that of Claudia Sanchez who did not leave her GitHub ID in the code?

rename.to: Duplicate MatrixProfile transformers? Why are there two?

body: If I remember correctly, one is a custom implementation for time series classification, the other one uses stumpy.
Claudia was an intern of mine a while back, I agree this needs looking at
We should also replace her print name with the GitHub ID to ensure conformance with the registry - do you have it?

I'm guessing it will be on the contributor list. Also adding sorting out MPDist to the to do list here, 
https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/sktime/distances/mpdist.py
it needs tidying up and converting to numba

In case it may be relevant to this group, in addition to computing a matrix profile (`stumpy.stump`), STUMPY also provides a [`stumpy.mpdist` function](https://stumpy.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html#stumpy.mpdist), which leverages `numba` out of the box. All of the code is unit tested and both `stump` and `mpdist` functions are parallelized to use all available cores, which means that it will be significantly faster than the current `numpy` implementation and will scale to much longer time series. STUMPY only depends on `numpy`, `scipy`, and `numba`, which are all dependencies of `sktime`. I hope that this information may be useful to you.

@seanlaw, the `MatrixProfileTransformer` already uses `stumpy` - so, can you explain why you are providing this information, or how it is relevant to the above? I may just be too stupid to see the connection, so feel free to explain it like to an elementary school pupil.
are you referring, perchance, to the `mpdist` in `sktime`?

@fkiraly Yes, my apologies for not being so clear. My comment was in response to @TonyBagnall but also, in general, that you may be able to replace all of the existing matrix profile code with STUMPY and avoid needing to maintain that code in `sktime`. Sorry for the confusion

>in general, that you may be able to replace all of the existing matrix profile code with STUMPY and avoid needing to maintain that code in sktime. Sorry for the confusion

I see!

While you are here, @seanlaw, do you perhaps understand the difference between the two matrix profile transformers in sktime?
I.e., why does one produce a series, and one non-time-ordered features? What are the outputs?

Alternatively, what is the matrix profile for you: an algorithm that produces a time series or sequence given a time series, or an algorithm that produces an unordered collection of features given a time series?

> While you are here, @seanlaw, do you perhaps understand the difference between the two matrix profile transformers in sktime? I.e., why does one produce a series, and one non-time-ordered features? What are the outputs?

> Alternatively, what is the matrix profile for you: an algorithm that produces a time series or sequence given a time series, or an algorithm that produces an unordered collection of features given a time series?

@fkiraly When I look at [series/matrix_profile.py](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/sktime/transformations/series/matrix_profile.py) and [panel/matrix_profile.py](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/sktime/transformations/panel/matrix_profile.py), for all intents and purposes, they both produce the same matrix profile output, which is a truncated 1D series that can be used to annotate the original input time series. Inherently, the matrix profile must be ordered and is **not** an unordered collection of features.

For your reference, [here is my explanation](https://stumpy.readthedocs.io/en/latest/Tutorial_The_Matrix_Profile.html) for what a "matrix profile" is and what information it captures.
